I was excited for the new standalone app, and assumed we would see some much-needed improvements, specifically protecting the app with a password just like the Android app.

I saw moxie’s response on github:
“We’re not going to be adding any local access control or protection. You can use Chrome profiles, full disk encryption, and a screenlock.”

github.com/signalapp/Signal-Desktop

Add option to lock the application

opened 02:11PM - 04 Dec 15 UTC
closed 06:51PM - 07 Dec 15 UTC
shaaati

While the phone app allows to lock the application with a passcode this is curre…ntly not possible on the desktop. From time to time, I give friends the permission to use my PC, e.g., for managing a music playlist or for quickly looking up something on the internet. Right now, everyone with access to my computer can open Chrome and look at all my synchronised conversations in Signal. I would feel more comfortable if I could, just as on the phone, set a passcode to unlock Signal on the desktop. (I don't know anything about how Chrome apps store data but maybe this could as well be used to encrypt the database itself.)

This repsonse is from 2015 - it’s now 2 months away from 2018 and Wickr is way ahead on the desktop app front, because they have these basic security features. I believe you guys should really reconsider your position on this. It’s a big deterrent for potential desktop users, I know of more than a few contacts of mine who refuse to install either desktop app for Signal.

It’s also shameful that the iOS version doesn’t have password protection, but I don’t use iOS so whatever. Truly not sure how the most secure, peer-reviewed, encrypted messaging app in the world (my words) is not interested in adding something as simple as password protection.

If you blow this off, I’ll happily continue to use the truly secure Android app. That version of Signal is a masterpiece.

Thanks for hearing me out

I think the consensus is that the system should be secured via other means ( full disk encryption, a good password etc)

Even Android password will eventually be removed since the most recent few versions of Android are starting for force full disk encryption.

Disagree my man. Consensus of whom? Doubt it is end-users. If it’s the developers, they should try and get an actual consensus of real users, instead of assuming that they know what everyone wants and needs, then just pointing to OS options that don’t address the issue at all of the application itself.

I have full disk encryption, DMA devices blocked over Firewire and Thunderbolt via multiple forbidden class IDs, screen lock with a hard limit on unlock attempts, etc. etc. - but that goes out the window when you are just trying to let someone use your PC/phone for a second and all sense of privacy is destroyed when they can just click the Signal icon.

Would be an absolute disgrace if the Android app regresses on features and REMOVES something that makes a SECURE MESSAGING APP, MORE SECURE.

Is it really such a hard ask? I am not requesting the desktop app to have all it’s data encrypted with this password, I agree full-disk encryption should be considered for such use cases. I am simply suggesting an OPTIONAL gate-keeping password to prevent people clicking on the icon and seeing every single private message. Can’t believe this concept seems so unacceptable to the devs, dude

giving someone else access to my PC/phone for a quick search, or something innocuous

That’s essentially true of anything under my user profile, which is why most operating systems have guest account functionality. I understand your concerns, but I feel that the reason OWS rejected this idea is because it’s an edge case solved by functionality built into the operating system.

nrizzio:

That’s essentially true of anything under my user profile, which is why most operating systems have a guest account of some kind. I understand your concerns, but I feel that the reason OWS rejected this idea is because it’s an edge case and there are solutions that already exist to mitigate the sources of problems.

And the easiest, most common “mitigation” is going to be to avoid their insecure implementations (iOS, Chrome, Standalone Desktop) like the plague. I understand exactly where you guys are coming from, but I’m feeling like my point of view is being utterly neglected by way of whataboutism. I’m never going to add a guest user to my computer or phone, and I’m VERY RARELY going to allow someone to use my computer or phone… but any time I do, I will have to make sure the desktop app is completely nuked from my computer.

This means OWS software is gone from everything except my Android device, until people/developers can meet in the middle and understand that something as utterly simple as a gatekeeper password would alleviate this issue ENTIRELY. Guess it’s gonne be the (actually secure) Wickr app on the desktop until then.

I understand your point, and it is nice to have Signal password protect feature. I also understand developers would like to focus on security between devices (data in transit) and not on device itself.

It is still a question do you only want to protect Signal app from “innocent look”? What about other data on your desktop/phone? I think on desktop you should create another user (some OS-es have support for guest user) and the same on phone. I never ever give a phone to someone else hands without going into guest account. The same on desktop, quick login to another (e.g. guest) user is a must.

Firstly I do not understand why the issues with the desktop app being unpassworded are ignored. Perhaps it should be looked at again, considering that this is not a chrome plugin issue any longer.

  1. The app stores messages locally and they do appear encrypted in the db.
  2. The app does not require the phone to be on (or decrypted) to show the message history thus rendering the local message store encryption pretty pointless if you do not need a password to decrypt that store - you just run the app.
  3. If you copy the directories in %appdata% and place onto another machine - can you read the message history there ? I haven’t tried this yet.

Passwording access to the app or giving the option to auto-lock after x minutes would be very useful but what about requiring the connected device to be present and responsive (i.e. not locked) ? You cannot send messages from the app with the phone locked - can you still receive them ?

Edit: You can send and receive messages with the phone locked. On iOS and Android you can receive messages with the phone completely off. iOS seems to allow sending with the phone off as well.

I’ve been an Android Signal app user for at least a year, maybe two. Just downloaded the desktop app and one of the very first things that I looked for was how to set the password. I couldn’t find it and hunted long enough to end up signed up in this forum, so I vote in favor. Since there was no way to protect the data in the desktop app, I decided to set messages to disappear on the desktop app after an hour. I figured I could always look at the history on my phone. Then I discovered that the disappearing message feature was also applied to my phone. Luckily, I discovered this limitation (or feature?) before the messages on my phone started to delete themselves.

It would be preferable if the password encrypted the data store on my hard drive, but mostly I’d like to restrict access to the desktop app either way. The app is on my home computer. I don’t routinely lock Windows or make the rare occasional guest user log into a completely separate Windows account, but also don’t leave personal data and messages one double-click away…

For comparison, I use gmail via the web browser. I usually use incognito mode so it doesn’t remain open/exposed/accessible to others when I close the browser.

I haven’t been using any kind of password access on my Android app because the phone locks itself after about a minute and must be re-opened. But, I may change that policy because, as a Red Cross volunteer, I have handed my phone to people to let them make a phone call at the scene of a personal disaster. Probably need to rethink my message notifications, too. The phone doesn’t leave my sight, but security has to involve the endpoints or it’s not end-to-end.

Desktop locking is a priority issue for me. I’ll play with the desktop app for a while, but it may go away if I’m not comfortable with the security and relative ease of maintaining my privacy.
Agree completely. This should not be “low priority” in my opinion
